title: National-Security Worries Threaten Takeover of U.K. Defense Firm
text:
LONDON—The U.K. halted the $5 billion sale of a British defense company to an American investor on national-security grounds, pending further government review, in a rare move for a country that hasn’t typically inserted itself in big, cross-border deal making.

The intervention comes as critics of the deal for Cobham COB -0.47% PLC—which makes air-to-air refueling systems and communications equipment for military and commercial planes—have said the planned acquisition is counter to national interest and undervalues the company. Some lawmakers and the founding Cobham family, which retains a small stake, have opposed the proposed purchase by U.S. private-equity firm Advent International Corp. Earlier this week, shareholders overwhelmingly approved it.

The British government has rarely inserted itself in such deals, though it has recently strengthened its powers of review amid similar new scrutiny in the U.S. and Europe. That new sensitivity has come amid a wave of acquisitions in strategic industries by Chinese companies.

The move represents a significant departure for the U.K., which has traditionally had a hands-off approach to other big deals. London, for instance, didn’t stand in the way of a $32 billion deal in 2016 by Japan’s SoftBank to buy Arm Holdings, a tech giant whose chip designs are in most of the world’s smartphones. The government did, though, secure a legally binding commitment from SoftBank to retain Arm’s U.K. headquarters. It is in talks with Advent about securing similar pledges.

The government on Wednesday said it had triggered an investigation of the deal. British competition officials will now prepare a report on the national-security aspects of the transaction and detail their findings by Oct. 29.

“Following careful consideration of the proposed takeover of Cobham, I have issued an intervention notice on the grounds of national security,” said Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom. “The government’s goals are to support private sector innovation whilst safeguarding the public interest.”

Cobham employs about 10,000 people, including around 1,700 in the U.K. It generated revenue of £1.86 billion ($2.32 billion) for 2018, with more than half its sales in the U.S. U.K. military spending accounting for less than 5% of its business.

A spokesman for Advent said the Boston-based firm was “committed to being a responsible steward” of the company, and would continue to engage constructively with the government as part of the review.

A spokesman for Cobham said the company would clarify its activities in the context of national security and “assuage the concerns that have been expressed by certain shareholders.”

The U.K. has long had the power to intervene in transactions but rarely does. Last year, it moved to bolster its powers to block foreign acquisitions of British companies, patents and other assets that it believes could compromise the country’s national security. Since 2002 the government has intervened on nine occasions to review takeovers on national security grounds.

The new rules, which paved the way for the government to intervene in a wider range of sectors and small transactions, were widely seen as a response to China’s appetite for technology and intellectual property. The U.S. and Germany have also boosted powers to scrutinize transactions.
